docs.lead_paragraph: Prices of finished goods as they left the factory rose a mild two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today. The report was fresh evidence that the recession is taking the steam out of inflation. The rise in prices that manufacturers charge for goods sold to wholesalers and distributors was the first after four months of declines. But the increase resulted mostly from flukes in two areas -- fresh vegetables and tobacco products -- rather than from strong demand driving up prices, said Craig Howell, chief for producer prices at the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline.main: Mild Rise in Producer Price Index

docs.lead_paragraph: In what President Bush's doctors said was a bizarre twist to his medical story, his overactive thyroid was found today to be caused by the same, noncontagious thyroid condition for which his wife, Barbara, is being treated. The condition is Graves' disease, an affliction in which the immune system inexplicably attacks the gland in the neck. Minutes after Mr. Bush was told that he had Graves' disease at Bethesda Naval Hospital early this morning, he sipped a radioactive iodine solution through a straw to stop his thyroid from overacting. Then he declared that he felt "perfect."

headline.main: In Strange Twist, Bush Is Suffering From Same Gland Disease as Wife

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush began a series of tests today to determine how to treat an overactive thyroid that his doctors say led to the erratic heart rhythm that put him in the hospital last weekend. Because the erratic heart rhythm returned briefly Tuesday night, the White House said today that Mr. Bush's doctors had prescribed an anticoagulant drug, Coumadin, to help prevent the formation of blood clots in his heart. Pieces of such clots, which can form as a complication of the erratic rhythm, can break off to cause strokes.

headline.main: Bush Begins Tests to Treat Thyroid That Disrupted Heart Rhythm

docs.lead_paragraph: An overactive thyroid that is easily treatable caused the irregular heartbeat that struck President Bush on Saturday and put him in a hospital for two nights, the President's physicians said today. Dr. Burton J. Lee 3d, the President's official doctor, said he was "very pleased" that the cause of Mr. Bush's heart flutter was not more serious. But he said the President's medical team would need at least a week to decide on the best treatment.

headline.main: BUSH'S PHYSICIANS SAY THYROID GLAND DISRUPTED HEART
